questions.question_text: What should an auditor do when assessing the business continuity plan (BCP) and disaster recovery (DR) of a cloud customer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
When assessing the business continuity plan (BCP) and disaster recovery (DR) of a cloud customer, an auditor should:

A. Evaluate the service level agreement (SLA) through a BCP/DR lens.

This option is most appropriate because it involves examining the SLA to ensure that it adequately addresses BCP and DR considerations. The auditor should assess whether the SLA includes provisions for continuity and recovery in the event of disruptions, and whether these provisions align with the organization's business continuity and recovery objectives. This evaluation helps ensure that the cloud service provider's commitments are sufficient to meet the organization's needs in a BCP/DR scenario.

Selected Answer: A

questions.question_text: When capturing compliance objectives within an organization’s cloud policy, it is MOST important for stakeholders to:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. take into consideration the organization’s risk appetite.

When capturing compliance objectives within an organization’s cloud policy, it is most important for stakeholders to take into consideration the organization’s risk appetite. This is because risk appetite defines the level and types of risk an organization is willing to accept in order to achieve its objectives. Aligning compliance objectives with the organization's risk appetite ensures that the cloud policy is tailored to the specific risk tolerance and strategic goals of the organization, facilitating effective risk management and decision-making processes.

Selected Answer: A
P#311 Risk perspective involves evaluating how the program has a comprehensive perspective on sources of risk and evaluating the alignment between the compliance objectives and risk appetite.
P# 312 The alignment between compliance objectives and risk appetite is accomplished by leveraging tools such as dashboards or records of vulnerability information. Those tools are used to make information available to the relevant teams, and to connect with other important tools, such as GRC tools

questions.question_text: To minimize the risk of noncompliance with regulatory equipment when switching to a new cloud service, it is MOST important to:

choices.A: adopt a hard-cutover approach to minimize the risk of data loss.
choices.C: seek assurances from peer organizations already using the proposed cloud service.
choices.B: test and validate that the new service meets predefined security targets.
choices.D: ensure the new service provider includes a pilot option of the cloud solution.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When switching to a new cloud service, minimizing the risk of noncompliance with regulatory requirements is crucial. Among the options provided, the most important step is:

B. Test and validate that the new service meets predefined security targets.

Testing and validating the new cloud service against predefined security targets is essential to ensure that it meets the necessary regulatory and compliance requirements. This process involves assessing whether the service provides the required security controls, data protection measures, and compliance features that align with the organization's regulatory obligations. By thoroughly evaluating the service before fully transitioning, you can mitigate risks associated with noncompliance and ensure that the new service supports your organization's compliance strategy effectively.

questions.question_text: From a systems development life cycle perspective, where a Software as a Service (SaaS) provider follows a DevOps approach, it is MOST beneficial for continuous auditing controls to be:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
From a systems development life cycle perspective, particularly when a Software as a Service (SaaS) provider follows a DevOps approach, it is MOST beneficial for continuous auditing controls to be:

A. designed natively into the software.

Designing auditing controls natively into the software ensures that these controls are an integral part of the system from the outset. This approach aligns well with the DevOps philosophy, which emphasizes collaboration and integration throughout the development process. By embedding auditing controls directly into the software, organizations can ensure consistent and automated monitoring, making it easier to detect and address issues as they arise. This also facilitates real-time compliance and security management, which is critical in a fast-paced DevOps environment.

CCAK Study Guide. Page 320.
6.8.2 Continuous Auditing and Continuous Assurance
"...Depending on the level of assurance the organization would need to obtain from its CSP and the level it would need to provide to its shareholders, customer and regulators, the assessors should focus on understanding the following:
(...)
if the organization follows a DevOps approach, are the controls natively designed into the software?.

Selected Answer: A
CCAK P# 321 Depending on the level of assurance the organization would need to obtain from its CSP and the level it would need to provide to its shareholders, customer and regulators, the assessors should focus on understanding the following:
• Whether the frequency of the control evaluation is aligned with the level of assurance required
• Whether the controls are designed to meet the requested testing and evaluation frequency (e.g., if the organization follows a DevOps approach, are the controls natively designed into the software?)
• Whether the source of evidence allows for continuous auditing (Are logs and feeds available with the level of details and frequency required? Are the logging and monitoring capabilities natively provided by the CSP sufficient, or do external tools need to be integrated? Is the reporting from the CSP, e.g., incident reporting, aligned with the organization’s compliance needs?)

questions.question_text: A cloud service provider utilizes services of other service providers for its cloud service. Which of the following is the BEST approach for the auditor while performing the audit for the cloud service?

choices.D: As the relationship between the cloud service provider and its service providers is governed by separate contracts between them, there is no need for the auditor to review the services provided by the service providers.
choices.B: The auditor should review the relationship between the cloud service provider and its service provider to help direct and estimate the level of effort and analysis the auditor should apply.
choices.A: The auditor should review the service providers’ security controls even more strictly, as they are further separated from the cloud customer.
choices.C: As the contract for the cloud service is between the cloud customer and the cloud service provider, there is no need for the auditor to review the services provided by the service providers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. The auditor should review the relationship between the cloud service provider and its service provider to help direct and estimate the level of effort and analysis the auditor should apply.

This option is the best approach because understanding the contractual and operational relationships between the cloud service provider and its underlying service providers is crucial. It helps the auditor assess how the dependencies and shared responsibilities might impact the security, compliance, and performance of the cloud services being provided to the customer. This understanding guides the auditor in determining the extent to which they need to evaluate the controls and processes of the third-party service providers, ensuring a comprehensive audit.

Selected Answer: B
CCAK P# 67 Cloud customers can be challenged to show auditors that the organization is in compliance. Assignment of compliance responsibilities to the provider and customer, and to indirect providers (i.e., the CSP of your CSP), can help both the cloud customer and the auditors.
